subject: Re: Junit 3 suite setup tear down
msgSnippet: ... Hello, David! Sorry, for long delay. ... I don t actually understand your question. Do you mean to define some BaseEJBTest class with @BeforeClass public
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <david@...> wrote:
Hello, David!
Sorry, for long delay.

>
> On Mon, Aug 4, 2008 at 4:52 PM, toalexsmail <toalexsmail@...> wrote:
> > No, I am not. I just want that doYourOneTimeSetup() would be run once
> > for ANY suite that run. doYourOneTimeSetup() will startup
> > microcontainer. Parameters to it doesn't changdes.
>
> Can you define doYourOneTimeSetup in a superclass of the suites, and
> have all of your suites inherit from it?
I don't actually understand your question. Do you mean to define some
BaseEJBTest class with

@BeforeClass
public static void setUpClass();
?

All test classes will inherit from this class. In this cases, however,
BaseEJBTest.setUpClass() will be called for all test class in the
suite. This is actually what I did. There is work-around, namely, to
use Bootstrap.getInstance().isStarted() to determine whether this is
first call to this method or not.
Perhaps, you meant to use something like this
> @RunWith(Suite.class)
> @SuiteClasses(A.class, B.class)
> public class MySuite {
> @BeforeClass public static void doYourOneTimeSetup() {}
> @AfterClass public static void doYourOneTimeTeardown() {}
> }
?
First of all, until recently I wasn't aware of this opportunity.
Second of all, it is quite verbose and not very flexible.

> >> Choosing individual methods to run
> >> from the command line or Eclipse is fairly simple, but mixing and
> >> matching methods from multiple classes takes a fair amount of magic.
> >> Do you find yourself wanting to do this often? (I usually am either
> >> running a whole suite, one class in the suite, or one method).
> > When I write some code or fix the bug I usually want to run some
> > subgroup of the test suite. I should split up my suite to the smaller
> > one, I know, but I couldn't to do it easily and, in fact, architecture
> > don't want to do it.
>
> So the suite that you want to run often involves one method, but not
> all, from class A, and one method, but not all, from class B? I'm
> sorry to ask the same question again, but I couldn't parse your answer
> (not enough coffee yet).
>
Usually I want to run 2,3 or 10 method from some class A. Typical use
case is the following (after I finished to write unit test and I want
to refactor the code\improve the code\find bug in production).
1. Run all test classes that cover the method to change. Usually it is
one class (this has a drawback to have huge test classes).
2. Figure out what test method has failed (after I made a change, I am
not describing a process of refactoring in detail here). Usually all
these methods belongs to one familiar that under normal circumstances
will be in different class.
3. Rerun only those methods.
4. Make a change to test method\method and rerun those methods, test
methods that failed, one particular test method, based on what is best
feet in this case.

I hope this helps.
